did.abstract: The Rita Schwartz photographs of Brownsville is comprised of one sheet of five black-and-white photographic prints depicting the Brownsville neighborhood of Brooklyn circa 1945 to 1953.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rita Schwartz photographs of Brownsville is comprised of one sheet of five black-and-white photographic prints depicting the Brownsville neighborhood of Brooklyn circa 1945 to 1953. Three of the images show Rita Gutter (later Rita Schwartz) on Amboy Street circa 1945. One image shows Owen Schwartz, Rita's son, on Amboy Street circa 1953, and the remaining image shows an unidentified man crossing Amboy Street circa 1945.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Rita Schwartz (nee Gutter) lived in the Brownsville neighborhood of Brooklyn in the 1940s and early 1950s. She attended Girls' Commercial High School (now Prospect Heights High School) located on Classon Avenue and graduated in 1946. Schwartz worked as an illustrator in the Art Department of the Associated Merchandising Corporation and also attended art school at the Brooklyn Museum. She left Brooklyn in 1953 and later studied fine art, painting, and print making at Pratt Graphics Center (an extension of Pratt Institute) in Manhattan following her marriage and the birth of her children. In 1989, Schwartz lived in Roslyn N.Y. and had become a jewelry designer. She died in 2007.
